abstracts.cdata!:
After the war ended in Bosnia and
            Herzegovina in 1995, unemployment reached 70 to 80 percent,
            and the population grappled with both post-war
            reconstruction and the emerging market economy. Microcredit
            offered the promise of helping poor people get back on their
            feet. Two Local Initiatives Projects launched in 1996 and
            2002 helped small entrepreneurs all over the country start
            anew. Special attention was given to those displaced by war,
            demobilized soldiers, and people disabled during the war. A
            total of about US$45 million helped establish eight
            microcredit organizations. People get loans from us much
            faster and more flexibly than from banks, emphasizes Mirsad
            Milavic, general manager of Sunrise, one of the eight
            organizations. Our credit officers are on the ground,
            visiting borrowers, and getting to know the businesses.
